(Latin music)
Anywhere I travel in Mexico,
the thing that I love eating most is
anything made with fresh masa.

Quesadillas, tortillas,
tamales, huaraches,
they are absolutely incredible.

Imagine eating sliced
white bread all your life,
and all of a sudden you're introduced to

fermented sourdough or a
baguette or a croissant.

There's no comparison,
and that's exactly what

eating something made
with fresh masa is like.

Corn is a foundational
ingredient in Mexican cuisine,

and almost every dish is
built around fresh corn.

It's one of the things
that I love eating most,

and it's something that
I want you to try, too.
(Latin music)
Welcome to Mexico. Pruébalo.
(birds chirping)
Choco and I are in a cornfield in

Jala Nayarit. I'm
meeting my friend Victor.
He is the owner of a business in Tepic

that is dedicated to preserving
native Mexican products.
One of its focuses right now is corn,
and that's the reason why I know him.
When I was writing my book,

I wanted to use the most
beautiful, most delicious corn

I could find, and his
corn is some of the best
in the whole country.
And so, I wanted to come visit him,
see this amazing corn in the field,

and learn how to make masa
in his (in foreign language).
(Latin music)
(calm Latin music)

Good boy, good boy, good
boy. (chuckles) Choco.

Nixtamalización is the
process used to make
hominy, masa, and masa harina.
A type of field corn called flint

is boiled in water and
cal, or pickling lime,

then left to steep
until the corn is tender

and the tough outer hull
is soft and easily removed.
This cooked corn is called hominy
and is used to make pozole.

To make masa, the cooked
corn is stone ground
until a soft, sticky dough forms.

This dough is called
masa and is used to make
tortillas, tamales, and tostadas.
To make masa harina, the fresh ground masa

is dried and pulverized
into a fine powder.

This flour has a much longer
shelf life than fresh masa

and can be mixed with water
to make tortillas and tamales.
Okay.
(Latin music)
Ah okay, wow.

And that's it. This masa
is ready to be transformed
into whatever you wanna make with it.

But today, I'm in the
mood for fresh tortillas
to make some incredibly rich pork tacos.
(upbeat Latin music)

And sopes, a slightly
thicker corn tortilla
with a pinched rim around the edge

to hold in refried beans,
salsas, and quesos.
And my absolute favorite, tamales:

steamed corn dumplings
filled with chicken, mole,
and wrapped in banana leaves.
(upbeat Latin music)

Corn is the backbone of
Mexican civilization.

There would not be a
culture, there would not be
the civilization without corn.
And apart from that, it's, like, it's
one of the most incredible flavors.

To me, it's what really makes
Mexican food Mexican food.

Eating fresh masa made
with freshly ground corn
is one of the most amazing
culinary experiences I've ever had.

It's why I wanted to
show you what it's like
to eat fresh corn and go out in the field
and see what it actually looks like.

So, I really hope that
you try it, I really hope

you enjoyed this episode,
and make sure you tag us

in your tortillas or
tamales that you make.

I wanna see definitely everything
you do with fresh masa,

and I can't wait to show you
my next adventure on Pruébalo.
